UConn closes seven academic programs, plans to review 70 moreNatasha Sokoloff8/12/2025

The review of low-enrollment programs at the University of Connecticut has resulted in seven program closures, and 70 will be monitored in the new school year.

CT Insider, all daily sites, UConn, Board of Trustees Academic Affairs Committee, College of Liberal Arts, Academic Affairs Committee, Office, Department of Mathematics, Anne D'Alleva, B.A., CT Insider, B.S., Mathematics-Physics, Applied Mathematical Sciences, Medieval Studies, College ofLiberal Arts, School of Medicine) B.A., Popular Culture, Environmental Sciences, Applied Mathematics, Pure Mathematics, Applied Mathematical Sciences, Financial Technology, Mathematics Teaching, Neag School of Education) Graduate Certificate in Addiction Sciences, Institute forCollaboration on Health, Intervention, and Policy) Graduate Certificate in School Law, Global Health (Institute for Collaboration on Health,Intervention, and Policy) Graduate Certificate Obesity Prevention and Weight ManagementRead

          </style><script type="application/ld+json" id="page-json-ld-0" data-next-head="">{"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"NewsArticle","mainEntityOfPage":"https://www.ctinsider.com/news/education/article/uconn-programs-majors-review-closure-monitoring-20811732.php","url":"https://www.ctinsider.com/news/education/article/uconn-programs-majors-review-closure-monitoring-20811732.php","headline":"UConn closes seven academic programs, plans to review 70 more","articleSection":"News/Education","publisher":{"@type":"NewsMediaOrganization","name":"CT Insider","logo":{"@type":"ImageObject","width":600,"height":60,"url":"https://www.ctinsider.com/sites/premiumctpost/ldjson_logo.png"},"location":{"@type":"Place","name":"CT Insider","address":{"@type":"PostalAddress","addressLocality":"Bridgeport","addressRegion":"CT"}},"url":"https://www.ctinsider.com","sameAs":["https://www.facebook.com/InsiderCT/","https://twitter.com/insider_ct","https://www.instagram.com/insider_ct/"]},"description":"The review of low-enrollment programs at the University of Connecticut has resulted in seven program closures, and 70 will be monitored in the new school year.","image":{"@type":"imageObject","width":2048,"height":1283,"url":"https://s.hdnux.com/photos/01/53/54/56/28232589/5/rawImage.jpg","thumbnailUrl":"https://s.hdnux.com/photos/01/53/54/56/28232589/5/square_small.jpg","caption":"A view of UConn campus in Storrs, Conn., on Thursday Mar. 4, 2021."},"articleBody":"A review of low-enrollment academic programs at the University of Connecticut has so far resulted in seven closures, with dozens more being monitored this coming school year. The review has generated controversy at the university since it was underway last fall, with some faculty members and lawmakers decrying the potential cuts to majors while UConn officials describe it as a routine way to adapt to challenges. Anne D’Alleva, UConn's provost and executive vice president for academic affairs, presented an update on the review process during the Board of Trustees Academic Affairs Committee meeting earlier this month. D’Alleva said in the Aug. 5 meeting that this kind of review process is normal, describing it as \"good academic housekeeping\" to see how to continually improve academic offerings at the university. Her update detailed which programs have been shuttered so far, which majors are discontinued and which programs will continue to be monitored this upcoming school year, as the review is expected to continue into the future. \"The goal of this process is to identify programs that may no longer align with student interest or workforce needs and determine whether such programs should be revitalized, consolidated with other offerings, or phased out with the appropriate teach-out plans as necessary,\" according to the August 5 update document. The review of low-enrollment and low-completion academic programs specifically targeted programs that failed to meet a five-year threshold of 100 or fewer undergraduate degree completions, 25 or fewer graduate certificate completions, 50 or fewer master’s degree completions, or 10 or fewer doctoral degree completions.  Earlier discussions around cutting programs came as UConn was facing budget strains, in part due to the expiration of federal pandemic-relief money. Those fiscal challenges have still not eased following the passage of the new state budget and cuts from the federal level, as UConn is currently facing more than a $100 million deficit and bracing for more cuts. For the review, faculty, department heads and deans considered student demand, enrollment and completion trends, curricular alignment, financial sustainability and market relevance, according to the Aug. 5 document. \"The outcomes reflect a strategic effort to ensure that all programs contribute to the vitality of UConn’s academic mission,\" according to the document. So far, seven programs have been approved for permanent closure, three majors are being discontinued and approximately 70 programs are being monitored or expected to have future action as a result of the review, according to the August 5 update. These seven programs were approved for permanent closure: Graduate Certificate in Global Health (Institute for Collaboration on Health,Intervention, and Policy) Graduate Certificate Obesity Prevention and Weight Management (Institute forCollaboration on Health, Intervention, and Policy) Graduate Certificate in School Law (Neag School of Education) Graduate Certificate in Addiction Sciences (School of Medicine) B.A. and B.S. in Applied Mathematical Sciences, BS in Mathematics-Physics (College ofLiberal Arts & Sciences) M.A. in Politics and Popular Culture (College of Liberal Arts & Sciences) MA and PhD in Medieval Studies (College of Liberal Arts & Sciences) According to the Aug. 5 document, the closures were made after consideration of factors such as persistent low enrollment, limited demand, and lack of alignment with current university priorities, as well as the review and approval of the Academic Affairs Committee. \"And of course this is the cycle of program life, that there are programs that sometimes it is time to close them for a variety of reasons,\" D’Alleva said in the meeting. Three other majors are being discontinued, as part of consolidation efforts. In the Department of Mathematics, Applied Mathematical Sciences (B.A.), Applied Mathematical Sciences (B.S.) and Mathematics-Physics (B.S.) are being discontinued, with the final term for new admissions this fall, according to the document. \"These changes streamline the department’s offerings, align more closely with peer institutions, and strengthen the core mathematics major, which now includes tracks in Pure Mathematics, Applied Mathematics, and Mathematics Teaching,\" according to the document. \"This is a strong example of preserving robust academic options while eliminating unnecessary duplication and creating greater clarity for students, thereby supporting student success.\" And those majors may not be the only ones no longer being offered at UConn. \"We expect additional consolidation efforts of this kind in the upcoming academic year,\" the update says. In addition, approximately 70 programs are being monitored or expected to have future action beginning in the 2025-26 academic year, according to the update. That means programs were approved to continue, but will be subject to focused monitoring and development of action plans aimed at improving enrollment and completion rates, undergoing regular review to evaluate strategies like revised curricula, enhanced marketing, and partnerships that may increase visibility and student interest, according to the document. The provost's office essentially has asked faculty and departments to take a look at these programs and to think about what they can do to enhance enrollment, D’Alleva said in the meeting. The list includes a range of programs, from the bachelor's in Environmental Sciences to the master's in Financial Technology. The provost's office, in partnership with the deans, will track outcomes for these programs and assess progress annually starting in the upcoming school year, according to the August 5 document. \"The Provost’s Office will continue to engage the Board of Trustees Academic Affairs Committee as this work evolves and will provide timely updates on future program evaluations and decisions,\" according to the href="https://www.ctinsider.com/news/education/article/uconn-majors-cut-programs-report-provosts-review-19968660.php" data-link="native" class="">review</a> of low-enrollment academic programs at the University of Connecticut has so far resulted in seven closures, with dozens more being monitored this coming school year.</p></div><div data-eid="item-100643" id="" class="mb32 ar16-9"><img src="https://cdn-channels-pixel.ex.co/events/0012000001fxZm9AAE?integrationType=DEFAULT&template=design%2Farticle%2Fplatypus_two_column.tpl" alt="" class="x1px y1px vh abs" aria-hidden="true" width="1" height="1"/><div id="7c9c07bc-55a8-4a33-aff9-9e2b0de6996a"></div></div><div class="r1udwkp5 d1uy5mhj articleBody mb32" data-block-type="text" data-dropcap="false"><p>The <a href="https://www.ctinsider.com/news/education/article/uconn-majors-cut-programs-report-provosts-review-19968660.php" data-link="native" class="">review</a> has generated controversy at the university since it was underway last fall, with some <a href="https://www.ctinsider.com/news/education/article/uconn-major-cuts-low-enrollment-evaluation-process-19845973.php" data-link="native" class="">faculty</a> members and <a href="https://www.ctinsider.com/news/education/article/martin-looney-uconn-lamont-cuts-19879425.php" data-link="native" class="">lawmakers</a> decrying the potential cuts to majors while UConn officials describe it as a <a href="https://www.ctinsider.com/news/education/article/uconn-program-cuts-bot-meeting-vote-19969531.php" data-link="native" class="">routine way</a> to adapt to challenges.</p></div><div class="pt16 sy16 bb bt b-gray300 mb32"><div class=""><p class="uiHeader11 f aic jcc ttu">Advertisement</p><p class="uiTextSmall f aic jcc">Article continues below this ad</p></div><div data-block-type="ad" data-small-id="A300" data-large-id="Inline-1" data-unit="hnp-ctinsider.com/article_dtc" class="f jcc mnh250px sm:mnh600px ais lg:f lg:jcc lg:mnh250px lg:pb16 lg:aic"></div></div><div class="r1udwkp5 d1uy5mhj articleBody mb32" data-block-type="text" data-dropcap="false"><p>Anne D’Alleva, UConn's provost and executive vice president for academic affairs, presented an update on the review process during the Board of Trustees Academic Affairs Committee meeting earlier this month. D’Alleva said in the Aug. 5 meeting that this kind of review process is normal, describing it as "good academic housekeeping" to see how to continually improve academic offerings at the university.</p></div><div class="r1udwkp5 d1uy5mhj articleBody mb32" data-block-type="text" data-dropcap="false"><p>Her update detailed which programs have been <a href="https://www.ctinsider.com/news/education/article/uconn-program-cuts-bot-meeting-vote-19969531.php" data-link="native" class="">shuttered so far</a>, which majors are discontinued and which programs will continue to be monitored this upcoming school year, as the review is expected to continue into the future.</p></div><div data-block-type="inlinerecirculation" class="pb32"><div class="f mb32" data-block-type="text" data-dropcap="false"><p>"The goal of this process is to identify programs that may no longer align with student interest or workforce needs and determine whether such programs should be revitalized, consolidated with other offerings, or phased out with the appropriate teach-out plans as necessary," according to the August 5 update document. The review of low-enrollment and low-completion academic programs specifically targeted programs that failed to meet a five-year threshold of 100 or fewer undergraduate degree completions, 25 or fewer graduate certificate completions, 50 or fewer master’s degree completions, or 10 or fewer doctoral degree completions. </p></div><div class="md:pt16 md:sy16 md:bb md:bt b-gray300 mb32"><div class="vh class="r12zgbl0 ruduv2y">Add Preferred Source</div></a></div></div><div class="r1udwkp5 d1uy5mhj articleBody mb32" data-block-type="text" data-dropcap="false"><p><a href="https://www.ctinsider.com/news/education/article/uconn-major-cuts-low-enrollment-evaluation-process-19845973.php" data-link="native" class="">Earlier discussions</a> around cutting programs came as UConn was facing budget strains, in part due to the expiration of federal pandemic-relief money. Those fiscal challenges have still not eased following the passage of the new state budget and cuts from the federal level, as UConn is currently facing more than a <a href="https://www.ctinsider.com/news/education/article/uconn-budget-cuts-state-funding-ct-20391137.php" data-link="native" class="">$100 million deficit</a> and bracing for more cuts.</p></div><div><div data-block-type="factbox" class="mb40 p24 bg-gray100"><div class="bb b-primary pb8 mb24"><div class="rel"><h3 class="fw600 uiHeader9">More Information</h3></div></div><div class="oy-hidden rel d1gmexgk f9z8kwt"><div data-testid="html" data-server-side-rendered="true" class="r1udwkp5 uiTextLarge"><p>These are the programs identified for future review or monitoring beginning this academic year:</p>
<ul>
<li>Bachelor's Environmental Sciences</li>
<li>Bachelor's Environmental Studies</li>
<li>Bachelor's Sustainable Plant and Soil Systems</li>
<li>Master's Animal Science</li>
<li>Master's Exercise Prescription</li>
<li>Master's Natural Resources</li>
<li>Master's Nutritional Science</li>
<li>Master's Pathobiology</li>
<li>Master’s Regenerative Engineering</li>
<li>Bachelor's African/Africana Studies</li>
<li>Bachelor's Engineering Physics</li>
<li>Bachelor's Environmental Sciences</li>
<li>Bachelor's Environmental Studies</li>
<li>Bachelor's Latino and Latin American Studies</li>
<li>Bachelor's Linguistics/Philosophy</li>
<li>Bachelor's Linguistics/Psychology</li>
<li>Bachelor's American Sign Language Studies</li>
<li>Bachelor's Arabic and Islamic Civilization</li>
<li>Bachelor's Chinese</li>
<li>Bachelor's Classics/Ancient Med. Studies</li>
<li>Bachelor's French</li>
<li>Bachelor's German</li>
<li>Bachelor's Italian Literary & Cultural Studies</li>
<li>Bachelor's Judaic Studies</li>
<li>Bachelor's Marine Sciences</li>
<li>Bachelor's Maritime Studies</li>
<li>Bachelor's Structural Biology/Biophysics</li>
<li>Bachelor's Philosophy</li>
<li>Graduate Certificate Cognitive Science</li>
<li>Graduate Certificate Literary Translation</li>
<li>Graduate Certificate Logic</li>
<li>Graduate Certificate Race, Ethnicity, and Politics</li>
<li>Graduate Certificate Health Psychology</li>
<li>Graduate Certificate Occupational Health Psychology</li>
<li>Master's Environmental Earth Science</li>
<li>Master's Race, Ethnicity & Politics</li>
<li>Master's Latina/o and Latin Amer Studies</li>
<li>Bachelor's Biology Education</li>
<li>Bachelor's Chemistry Education</li>
<li>Bachelor's Earth Science Education</li>
<li>Bachelor's English Education</li>
<li>Bachelor's French Education</li>
<li>Bachelor's General Science Education</li>
<li>Bachelor's German Language Education</li>
<li>Bachelor's History/Social Studies Education</li>
<li>Bachelor's Mandarin Chinese Language Education</li>
<li>Bachelor's Mathematics Education</li>
<li>Bachelor's Music Education</li>
<li>Bachelor's Physics Education</li>
<li>Bachelor's Spanish Language Education</li>
<li>Bachelor's Special Education</li>
<li>Graduate Certificate Literacy Leadership</li>
<li>Graduate Certificate Licensed Professional Counselor</li>
<li>Bachelor's Health Care Management</li>
<li>Bachelor's Real Estate/Urban Economics</li>
<li>Master's Financial Technology</li>
<li>Bachelor's Acting</li>
<li>Bachelor's Design/Technical Theater</li>
<li>Bachelor's Puppetry</li>
<li>Bachelor’s Theatre Studies</li>
<li>Graduate Certificate Health Care Innovation</li>
<li>Graduate Certificate Pain Management</li>
<li>Graduate Certificate Systems Genomics: Clinical Communication and Counseling</li>
<li>Master’s Genetic Counseling</li>
<li>Master’s Polymer Science</li>
<li>Master’s Materials Science</li>
<li>Master’s Health Care Genetics</li>
<li>Doctoral Systems Genomics</li>
<li>Graduate Certificate Disabilities Studies in Public Health</li>
</ul></div></div></div></div><div class="r1udwkp5 d1uy5mhj articleBody mb32" data-block-type="text" data-dropcap="false"><p>For the review, faculty, department heads and deans considered student demand, enrollment and completion trends, curricular alignment, financial sustainability and market relevance, according to the Aug. 5 document. "The outcomes reflect a strategic effort to ensure that all programs contribute to the vitality of UConn’s academic mission," according to the document.</p></div><div class="pt16 sy16 bb bt b-gray300 mb32"><div class=""><p class="uiHeader11 f aic jcc ttu">Advertisement</p><p class="uiTextSmall f aic jcc">Article continues below this ad</p></div><div data-block-type="ad" data-small-id="Inline-1" data-large-id="Inline-3" data-unit="hnp-ctinsider.com/article_dtc" class="f jcc mnh250px pb16 aic lg:f lg:jcc lg:mnh250px lg:pb16 lg:aic"></div></div><div class="r1udwkp5 d1uy5mhj articleBody mb32" data-block-type="text" data-dropcap="false"><p>So far, seven programs have been approved for permanent closure, three majors are being discontinued and approximately 70 programs are being monitored or expected to have future action as a result of the review, according to the August 5 update.</p></div><div class="r1udwkp5 d1uy5mhj articleBody mb32" data-block-type="text" data-dropcap="false"><p>These seven programs were approved for permanent closure:</p></div><div class="r1udwkp5 d1uy5mhj articleBody mb32" data-block-type="text" data-dropcap="false"><ul>
<li>Graduate Certificate in Global Health (Institute for Collaboration on Health,<br/>Intervention, and Policy)</li>
<li>Graduate Certificate Obesity Prevention and Weight Management (Institute for<br/>Collaboration on Health, Intervention, and Policy)</li>
<li>Graduate Certificate in School Law (Neag School of Education)</li>
<li>Graduate Certificate in Addiction Sciences (School of Medicine)</li>
<li>B.A. and B.S. in Applied Mathematical Sciences, BS in Mathematics-Physics (College of<br/>Liberal Arts & Sciences)</li>
<li>M.A. in Politics and Popular Culture (College of Liberal Arts & Sciences)</li>
<li>MA and PhD in Medieval Studies (College of Liberal Arts & Sciences)</li>
</ul></div><div class="r1udwkp5 d1uy5mhj articleBody mb32" data-block-type="text" data-dropcap="false"><p>According to the Aug. 5 document, the closures were made after consideration of factors such as persistent low enrollment, limited demand, and lack of alignment with current university priorities, as well as the review and approval of the Academic Affairs Committee.</p></div><div class="pt16 sy16 bb bt b-gray300 mb32"><div class=""><p class="uiHeader11 f aic jcc ttu">Advertisement</p><p class="uiTextSmall f aic jcc">Article continues below this ad</p></div><div data-block-type="ad" data-small-id="Inline-2" data-large-id="Inline-4" data-unit="hnp-ctinsider.com/article_dtc" class="f jcc mnh250px pb16 aic lg:f lg:jcc lg:mnh250px lg:pb16 lg:aic"></div></div><div class="r1udwkp5 d1uy5mhj articleBody mb32" data-block-type="text" data-dropcap="false"><p>"And of course this is the cycle of program life, that there are programs that sometimes it is time to close them for a variety of reasons," D’Alleva said in the meeting.</p></div><div class="r1udwkp5 d1uy5mhj articleBody mb32" data-block-type="text" data-dropcap="false"><p>Three other majors are being discontinued, as part of consolidation efforts. In the Department of Mathematics, Applied Mathematical Sciences (B.A.), Applied Mathematical Sciences (B.S.) and Mathematics-Physics (B.S.) are being discontinued, with the final term for new admissions this fall, according to the document.</p></div><div class="r1udwkp5 d1uy5mhj articleBody mb32" data-block-type="text" data-dropcap="false"><p>"These changes streamline the department’s offerings, align more closely with peer institutions, and strengthen the core mathematics major, which now includes tracks in Pure Mathematics, Applied Mathematics, and Mathematics Teaching," according to the document. "This is a strong example of preserving robust academic options while eliminating unnecessary duplication and creating greater clarity for students, thereby supporting student success."</p></div><div class="r1udwkp5 d1uy5mhj articleBody mb32" data-block-type="text" data-dropcap="false"><p>And those majors may not be the only ones no longer being offered at UConn. "We expect additional consolidation efforts of this kind in the upcoming academic year," the update says.</p></div><div class="pt16 sy16 bb bt b-gray300 mb32"><div class=""><p class="uiHeader11 f aic jcc ttu">Advertisement</p><p class="uiTextSmall f aic jcc">Article continues below this ad</p></div><div data-block-type="ad" data-small-id="Inline-3" data-large-id="Inline-5" data-unit="hnp-ctinsider.com/article_dtc" class="f jcc mnh250px pb16 aic lg:f lg:jcc lg:mnh250px lg:pb16 lg:aic"></div></div><div class="r1udwkp5 d1uy5mhj articleBody mb32" data-block-type="text" data-dropcap="false"><p>In addition, approximately 70 programs are being monitored or expected to have future action beginning in the 2025-26 academic year, according to the update.</p></div><div class="r1udwkp5 d1uy5mhj articleBody mb32" data-block-type="text" data-dropcap="false"><p>That means programs were approved to continue, but will be subject to focused monitoring and development of action plans aimed at improving enrollment and completion rates, undergoing regular review to evaluate strategies like revised curricula, enhanced marketing, and partnerships that may increase visibility and student interest, according to the document.</p></div><div class="r1udwkp5 d1uy5mhj articleBody mb32" data-block-type="text" data-dropcap="false"><p>The provost's office essentially has asked faculty and departments to take a look at these programs and to think about what they can do to enhance enrollment, D’Alleva said in the meeting.</p></div><div class="pt16 sy16 bb bt b-gray300 mb32"><div class=""><p class="uiHeader11 f aic jcc ttu">Advertisement</p><p class="uiTextSmall f aic jcc">Article continues below this ad</p></div><div data-block-type="ad" data-small-id="Inline-4" data-large-id="Inline-6" data-unit="hnp-ctinsider.com/article_dtc" class="f jcc mnh250px pb16 aic lg:f lg:jcc lg:mnh250px lg:pb16 lg:aic"></div></div><div class="r1udwkp5 d1uy5mhj articleBody mb32" data-block-type="text" data-dropcap="false"><p>The list includes a range of programs, from the bachelor's in Environmental Sciences to the master's in Financial Technology. The provost's office, in partnership with the deans, will track outcomes for these programs and assess progress annually starting in the upcoming school year, according to the August 5 document.</p></div><div class="r1udwkp5 d1uy5mhj articleBody mb32" data-block-type="text" data-dropcap="false"><p>"The Provost’s Office will continue to engage the Board of Trustees Academic Affairs Committee as this work evolves and will provide timely updates on future program evaluations and decisions," according to the document.</p></div><div class="y1px x100 abs bgn top"></div><div style="top:25%" class="y1px x100 abs bgn"></div><div style="top:50%" class="y1px x100 abs bgn"></div><div style="top:75%" class="y1px x100 abs bgn"></div><div class="y1px x100 abs bgn bottom"></div></article></div><div view of UConn campus in Storrs, Conn., on Thursday Mar. 4, 2021."},"articleBody":"A review of low-enrollment academic programs at the University of Connecticut has so far resulted in seven closures, with dozens more being monitored this coming school year. The review has generated controversy at the university since it was underway last fall, with some faculty members and lawmakers decrying the potential cuts to majors while UConn officials describe it as a routine way to adapt to challenges. Anne D’Alleva, UConn's provost and executive vice president for academic affairs, presented an update on the review process during the Board of Trustees Academic Affairs Committee meeting earlier this month. D’Alleva said in the Aug. 5 meeting that this kind of review process is normal, describing it as \"good academic housekeeping\" to see how to continually improve academic offerings at the university. Her update detailed which programs have been shuttered so far, which majors are discontinued and which programs will continue to be monitored this upcoming school year, as the review is expected to continue into the future. \"The goal of this process is to identify programs that may no longer align with student interest or workforce needs and determine whether such programs should be revitalized, consolidated with other offerings, or phased out with the appropriate teach-out plans as necessary,\" according to the August 5 update document. The review of low-enrollment and low-completion academic programs specifically targeted programs that failed to meet a five-year threshold of 100 or fewer undergraduate degree completions, 25 or fewer graduate certificate completions, 50 or fewer master’s degree completions, or 10 or fewer doctoral degree completions.  Earlier discussions around cutting programs came as UConn was facing budget strains, in part due to the expiration of federal pandemic-relief money. Those fiscal challenges have still not eased following the passage of the new state budget and cuts from the federal level, as UConn is currently facing more than a $100 million deficit and bracing for more cuts. For the review, faculty, department heads and deans considered student demand, enrollment and completion trends, curricular alignment, financial sustainability and market relevance, according to the Aug. 5 document. \"The outcomes reflect a strategic effort to ensure that all programs contribute to the vitality of UConn’s academic mission,\" according to the document. So far, seven programs have been approved for permanent closure, three majors are being discontinued and approximately 70 programs are being monitored or expected to have future action as a result of the review, according to the August 5 update. These seven programs were approved for permanent closure: Graduate Certificate in Global Health (Institute for Collaboration on Health,Intervention, and Policy) Graduate Certificate Obesity Prevention and Weight Management (Institute forCollaboration on Health, Intervention, and Policy) Graduate Certificate in School Law (Neag School of Education) Graduate Certificate in Addiction Sciences (School of Medicine) B.A. and B.S. in Applied Mathematical Sciences, BS in Mathematics-Physics (College ofLiberal Arts \u0026 Sciences) M.A. in Politics and Popular Culture (College of Liberal Arts \u0026 Sciences) MA and PhD in Medieval Studies (College of Liberal Arts \u0026 Sciences) According to the Aug. 5 document, the closures were made after consideration of factors such as persistent low enrollment, limited demand, and lack of alignment with current university priorities, as well as the review and approval of the Academic Affairs Committee. \"And of course this is the cycle of program life, that there are programs that sometimes it is time to close them for a variety of reasons,\" D’Alleva said in the meeting. Three other majors are being discontinued, as part of consolidation efforts. In the Department of Mathematics, Applied Mathematical Sciences (B.A.), Applied Mathematical Sciences (B.S.) and Mathematics-Physics (B.S.) are being discontinued, with the final term for new admissions this fall, according to the document. \"These changes streamline the department’s offerings, align more closely with peer institutions, and strengthen the core mathematics major, which now includes tracks in Pure Mathematics, Applied Mathematics, and Mathematics Teaching,\" according to the document. \"This is a strong example of preserving robust academic options while eliminating unnecessary duplication and creating greater clarity for students, thereby supporting student success.\" And those majors may not be the only ones no longer being offered at UConn. \"We expect additional consolidation efforts of this kind in the upcoming academic year,\" the update says. In addition, approximately 70 programs are being monitored or expected to have future action beginning in the 2025-26 academic year, according to the update. That means programs were approved to continue, but will be subject to focused monitoring and development of action plans aimed at improving enrollment and completion rates, undergoing regular review to evaluate strategies like revised curricula, enhanced marketing, and partnerships that may increase visibility and student interest, according to the document. The provost's office essentially has asked faculty and departments to take a look at these programs and to think about what they can do to enhance enrollment, D’Alleva said in the meeting. The list includes a range of programs, from the bachelor's in Environmental Sciences to the master's in Financial Technology. The provost's office, in partnership with the deans, will track outcomes for these programs and assess progress annually starting in the upcoming school year, according to the August 5 document. \"The Provost’s Office will continue to engage the Board of Trustees Academic Affairs Committee as this work evolves and will provide timely updates on future program evaluations and decisions,\" according to the readabilityObject.title: UConn closes seven academic programs, plans to review 70 more
readabilityObject.content:
A review of low-enrollment academic programs at the University of Connecticut has so far resulted in seven closures, with dozens more being monitored this coming school year.

The review has generated controversy at the university since it was underway last fall, with some faculty members and lawmakers decrying the potential cuts to majors while UConn officials describe it as a routine way to adapt to challenges.

Article continues below this ad

Anne D’Alleva, UConn's provost and executive vice president for academic affairs, presented an update on the review process during the Board of Trustees Academic Affairs Committee meeting earlier this month. D’Alleva said in the Aug. 5 meeting that this kind of review process is normal, describing it as "good academic housekeeping" to see how to continually improve academic offerings at the university.

Her update detailed which programs have been shuttered so far, which majors are discontinued and which programs will continue to be monitored this upcoming school year, as the review is expected to continue into the future.

"The goal of this process is to identify programs that may no longer align with student interest or workforce needs and determine whether such programs should be revitalized, consolidated with other offerings, or phased out with the appropriate teach-out plans as necessary," according to the August 5 update document. The review of low-enrollment and low-completion academic programs specifically targeted programs that failed to meet a five-year threshold of 100 or fewer undergraduate degree completions, 25 or fewer graduate certificate completions, 50 or fewer master’s degree completions, or 10 or fewer doctoral degree completions. 

Article continues below this ad

Earlier discussions around cutting programs came as UConn was facing budget strains, in part due to the expiration of federal pandemic-relief money. Those fiscal challenges have still not eased following the passage of the new state budget and cuts from the federal level, as UConn is currently facing more than a $100 million deficit and bracing for more cuts.

For the review, faculty, department heads and deans considered student demand, enrollment and completion trends, curricular alignment, financial sustainability and market relevance, according to the Aug. 5 document. "The outcomes reflect a strategic effort to ensure that all programs contribute to the vitality of UConn’s academic mission," according to the document.

Article continues below this ad

So far, seven programs have been approved for permanent closure, three majors are being discontinued and approximately 70 programs are being monitored or expected to have future action as a result of the review, according to the August 5 update.

These seven programs were approved for permanent closure:

  • Graduate Certificate in Global Health (Institute for Collaboration on Health,
    Intervention, and Policy)
  • Graduate Certificate Obesity Prevention and Weight Management (Institute for
    Collaboration on Health, Intervention, and Policy)
  • Graduate Certificate in School Law (Neag School of Education)
  • Graduate Certificate in Addiction Sciences (School of Medicine)
  • B.A. and B.S. in Applied Mathematical Sciences, BS in Mathematics-Physics (College of
    Liberal Arts & Sciences)
  • M.A. in Politics and Popular Culture (College of Liberal Arts & Sciences)
  • MA and PhD in Medieval Studies (College of Liberal Arts & Sciences)

According to the Aug. 5 document, the closures were made after consideration of factors such as persistent low enrollment, limited demand, and lack of alignment with current university priorities, as well as the review and approval of the Academic Affairs Committee.

Article continues below this ad

"And of course this is the cycle of program life, that there are programs that sometimes it is time to close them for a variety of reasons," D’Alleva said in the meeting.

Three other majors are being discontinued, as part of consolidation efforts. In the Department of Mathematics, Applied Mathematical Sciences (B.A.), Applied Mathematical Sciences (B.S.) and Mathematics-Physics (B.S.) are being discontinued, with the final term for new admissions this fall, according to the document.

"These changes streamline the department’s offerings, align more closely with peer institutions, and strengthen the core mathematics major, which now includes tracks in Pure Mathematics, Applied Mathematics, and Mathematics Teaching," according to the document. "This is a strong example of preserving robust academic options while eliminating unnecessary duplication and creating greater clarity for students, thereby supporting student success."

And those majors may not be the only ones no longer being offered at UConn. "We expect additional consolidation efforts of this kind in the upcoming academic year," the update says.

Article continues below this ad

In addition, approximately 70 programs are being monitored or expected to have future action beginning in the 2025-26 academic year, according to the update.

That means programs were approved to continue, but will be subject to focused monitoring and development of action plans aimed at improving enrollment and completion rates, undergoing regular review to evaluate strategies like revised curricula, enhanced marketing, and partnerships that may increase visibility and student interest, according to the document.

The provost's office essentially has asked faculty and departments to take a look at these programs and to think about what they can do to enhance enrollment, D’Alleva said in the meeting.

Article continues below this ad

The list includes a range of programs, from the bachelor's in Environmental Sciences to the master's in Financial Technology. The provost's office, in partnership with the deans, will track outcomes for these programs and assess progress annually starting in the upcoming school year, according to the August 5 document.

"The Provost’s Office will continue to engage the Board of Trustees Academic Affairs Committee as this work evolves and will provide timely updates on future program evaluations and decisions," according to the document.

Aug 12, 2025

Natasha Sokoloff is a reporter with Hearst Connecticut Media Group covering education across the state. She reports on both K-12 schools and higher education, from federal and state policy impacts to inequities and other issues in Connecticut schools. She is originally from Southern California and graduated from the University of Richmond with a double major in journalism and leadership studies. Natasha previously covered the Farmington Valley area and has experience covering local news, public affairs and politics, art, education and social justice issues.
